page.title: 13LOCAL HISTORY: STATION
page.content: {Potton Railway Station}is{128}years old. At first the train went from {Potton to Sandy}and the first engine was called the{Shannon}which can be seen in a museum in Didcot. In 1862 the line became part of the{Bedford to {Cambridge}railway. The line closed in 1967. The old station has been made into a house, but the old{ticket office}is still there and the{waiting room}is now used as a store room. On the wall behind the platform hangs a sign advertising mustard. The canopy over the platform is in good condition and the iron work is worth seeing. In the pattern the letters{BC}can be seen. BC stands for{Bedford/Cambridge.}Where the footbridge used to cross the line potatoes are now growing. Both platforms, however, are still there as well as the sign saying{Potton.
